info.title: AI Use for Aided Teaching in Country’s Mainstream Classrooms

section.title: Introduction
section.para:
Artificial Intelligence (AI) is a disruptive technology, transforming industries such as healthcare, finance, media, and customer service [, , ,
]. Many organisations are integrating AI into their operations to enhance efficiency and productivity. Additionally, new applications and markets have emerged, in part due to AI, such as self-driving cars. AI has gone mainstream, its effect are being felt by most people, whether they are aware of it or not.

The development of AI began over 70 years , throughout its history, it has achieved spectacular feats, including challenging humans in chess and defeating a Grandmaster in 1988 ; making phone calls with natural-sounding synthetic voices, such as booking a restaurant table during a live event in 2018 . Then in 2022, ChatGPT’s ability to engage in human-like conversations, matched with remarkable intelligence, propelled it to phenomenal status, driving major investment and competition in generative AI .

Generative AI has gained rapid adoption, impressing both users and businesses. The current focus is now on its successful integration, as well as the challenges of introducing AI safely and productively. As highlighted by McKinsey's global survey , over three-quarters of organisations report using AI in at least one business function, with the use of generative AI increasing particularly rapidly. Following this widespread initial adoption, the focus for many companies is now increasingly on how to structure their AI initiatives to achieve meaningful financial benefits.

Generative AI, also referred to as GenAI, instantly generates content on demand, fulfilling entire user requests, such as "Make me a short film with pirates in space." When responding to user prompts, Generative AI analyses patterns in human language using deep learning and probability models to generate the most appropriate response.

The primary benefit of generative AI is its efficiency. It provides users with instant answers to their questions and can generate entire outputs, such as spreadsheets or programming code. This allows organizations to free up labor from repetitive tasks and focus on more critical work.

section.title: AI in the public sector
section.para: The Cabinets of the United Kingdom, under both Labour and Conservative governments, recognised this technological shift and pledged significant investments. The Conservative-led government, allocated £900 million to British AI projects , increased spending on related research, and backed the implementation of supercomputers to help with the intensive computational tasks of AI .

After taking office in 2024, the Labour government swiftly moved to cancel Edinburgh University's supercomputer project . Shortly after, the Prime Minister announced new initiatives to position AI as a central pillar of the UK's economic transformation. The government secured £14 billion in private investments and committed more spending to help realise this vision, signalling a strong shift in policy. Prime Minster Keir Starmer, speaking on behalf of the government, declared that Britain aims to become "one of the great AI superpowers" .

Alongside the announced investments, the Prime Minister stated that the government's strategy to embrace AI would "improve public services" and, in turn, transform the lives of working groups, with a specific focus on teachers. Given that teachers make up a large portion of public employees in the UK, this example was an important and relevant point to highlight, especially as public schooling faces increasing challenges.

Education and schooling is one of the UK's core public services, with over 29,000 schools across the entire UK. The sector employs around 1.23 million people, making up approximately 20% of the UK’s 6.12 million public sector workforce. In recent years, however, the attractiveness of teaching has fallen across Britain and working conditions have worsened. Within Scotland, staffing saw a steady increase in the pupil-teacher ratio, which currently stands at 13.3 students per teacher. The compensation of teachers is at risk too, with a rise in teachers leaving before completing their five-year tenure, according to the latest figures .

England faces a similar situation with a massive teacher recruitment shortage forecasted, and for the teachers currently employed, job dissatisfaction is severe, with 90% saying they have considered leaving their jobs due to high workloads. These reports came from the National Foundation for Educational Research (NFER).

The government aimed to tackle the situation by providing £1 million in funding to develop AI teaching tools. This investment has so far yielded tangible prototypes. The initiative is guided by the AI Opportunities Action Plan , devised by the government's AI adviser, Matt Clifford. According to the document, the newly created AI deployment is intended to prioritise public services as its primary customer. Additionally, the government has acknowledged that AI could replace certain civil service jobs, estimating significant reductions in the workforce over time .

The National Education Union (NEU) opposes moves to prioritise AI technologies at the expense of teacher employment, citing real concerns over weakening job security. They also argued that such tools devalue the profession by shifting teachers' roles from crafting high-quality lessons to merely administering the technology itself. Responding to the Prime Minister's speech, the NEU's general secretary criticised the exclusion of teaching experts from roll-out decisions, stating that "there had not been any meaningful discussion with the sector yet" .

section.title: Current AI tools in practise
section.para: The proof-of-concept AI tool, developed by Faculty for the Department of Education , explored the use of generative AI in evaluating lower-level English literacy material. It successfully provided feedback using GPT-4-turbo, and teachers generally found it highly useful, with some appreciating its time-saving aspects. While the associated press release highlighted the tool’s potential for high accuracy, the more detailed findings in the technical report, absent from the press release, revealed a decline in error-spotting accuracy when processing longer, more complex pieces of writing.

In the case of young students, four out of five teenagers (ages 13–17) engage with generative AI , and over half express interest in using AI for studying, according to recent reports . This trend extends to higher education, their closest counterpart, with UK universities increasingly disciplining students for using AI to cheat .

Artificial intelligence is already used in classrooms around the country, enhancing children's learning. At Tor Bank, a special needs school, AI has been used to help students communicate and be more creative. "Although our kids don't have voices sometimes, it's making their creations come alive," said Danielle Perry. She also highlighted that pupils were using AI to research and create presentations, demonstrating how alternative approaches can support their learning.

Moreover, David Game College designed a GCSE course to be "teacherless," where teenagers engage in one-on-one sessions with tech. Their AI-powered Adaptive Learner systems scores from these sessions to determine which coursework is flagged by a virtual tutor.

However, critics of AI tutors mostly center around the children's well-being. Chris McGovern, leader of the Campaign for Real Education, argued that building AI-driven classrooms could encroach on children's social skills. The 2025 NSPCC report on generative AI and child safety, strongly implied that children remain vulnerable to the technology's misuse due to companies existing insufficient safety measures.

Character AI is a platform to digitally chat through AI companionships simulating real and fictional people, with millions of users . The company publicly states user safety is a priority . However, despite these claims, CharacterAI is currently facing significant legal challenges due to lawsuits alleging harm to children and teenagers who have used the platform. One of the more extreme examples involved romancing and convincing a 14-year-old to commit suicide .

The risks associated with generative AI, as documented by experts, reinforce concerns over its unfettered operation. Many organisations have called on the government to implement safeguards against the rapid wave of AI innovations. However, the government has been slow to enact AI legislation, with Lord Holmes even accusing them of ignoring manifesto promises that called for such measures . They also rebranded the AI Safety Institute as the AI Security Institute. Notably, during a global summit in February, the government refused to sign an international AI declaration, citing a lack of "practical clarity."

section.title: Conclusion
section.para: The government's long-term support for AI has set the public sector on a path toward greater adoption. These initiatives were introduced to drive economic growth. However, this support has prompted unionised groups to defend job opportunities for teachers.

Furthermore, generative AI is now firmly in the public consciousness, with both teachers and students increasingly inclined to use the technology. Its benefits include enhancing learning environments by providing students with more ways to engage with the curriculum and allowing teachers to focus on higher-value tasks

Although AI has shown positive outcomes, critics argued that its impact on productivity could be a false economy. Regarding safety, concerns were raised about the risks for children proactively engaging with AI, particularly the potential for coercion of vulnerable children. Some experts advocated for a more proactive government response, believing that new legislation was necessary to protect people from the realities of AI.
